framework_metadata.name: Culturally Responsive Place-Based Lesson Plan Evaluation Framework
framework_metadata.context: K-12 Education in Aotearoa New Zealand
framework_metadata.author: Grace (ShuGrace) - UoA Educational Technology PhD
framework_metadata.description: Comprehensive framework for evaluating lesson plans across four dimensions: place-based learning, integrated cultural responsiveness (including Māori perspectives), critical pedagogy, and lesson design quality

changelog.v1.0: Initial framework with four separate dimensions (place_based, cultural, maori, critical)
changelog.v2.0: Attempted to merge cultural and Māori dimensions but retained separate indicator sections
changelog.v3.0: Complete integration of cultural responsiveness and Māori perspectives into unified indicators; added lesson design quality dimension for holistic evaluation

place_based_learning.label: Place-Based Learning
place_based_learning.definition: Teaching and learning grounded in local environment, community, and culture, connecting students deeply to the places where they live through authentic, real-world experiences

core_literature.citation: Sobel, D. (2004). Place-based education: Connecting classrooms and communities. Orion Society.
core_literature.key_contribution: Emphasizes using local community and environment as starting point; promotes interdisciplinary learning around local phenomena; cultivates attachment to place and environmental stewardship

core_literature.citation: Smith, G. A. (2007). Place-based education: Breaking through the constraining regularities of public school. Environmental Education Research, 13(2), 189-207.
core_literature.key_contribution: Challenges traditional schooling constraints; emphasizes community as classroom; values intergenerational learning and local knowledge transmission

core_literature.citation: Gruenewald, D. A. (2003). The best of both worlds: A critical pedagogy of place. Educational Researcher, 32(4), 3-12.
core_literature.key_contribution: Combines critical pedagogy with ecological education; emphasizes decolonization and reinhabitation; questions dominant narratives shaping places

indicators.name: Local Context Integration
indicators.definition: Uses students' surrounding environments, places, and resources as primary learning content
indicators.assessment_question: Does the lesson meaningfully reference specific local environments, landmarks, or community resources?

scoring_guide.5: Deeply embedded in specific local places; names specific locations, landmarks, ecosystems
scoring_guide.4: Strong local connections with clear geographic specificity
scoring_guide.3: Some local references but could be more specific or detailed
scoring_guide.2: Minimal local context; mostly generic or could be anywhere
scoring_guide.1: No meaningful local connection; entirely generic content

indicators.name: Community Engagement & Partnerships
indicators.definition: Involves authentic collaboration with community members, organizations, or uses community as classroom
indicators.assessment_question: Does the lesson involve partnerships with local experts, organizations, or community-based learning?

scoring_guide.5: Substantive community partnerships; co-designed with community; authentic collaboration
scoring_guide.4: Clear community involvement; local experts or organizations engaged
scoring_guide.3: Some community connection; limited depth or authenticity
scoring_guide.2: Minimal community involvement; mostly school-confined
scoring_guide.1: No community engagement; entirely classroom-based

indicators.name: Authentic Real-World Problem Solving
indicators.definition: Addresses genuine environmental or social issues in the local area with real consequences
indicators.assessment_question: Are students investigating or addressing actual problems facing their community?

scoring_guide.5: Addresses real community problems; potential for genuine impact; authentic stakeholders
scoring_guide.4: Engages with real local issues; meaningful authentic connection
scoring_guide.3: Some connection to real issues but limited authenticity
scoring_guide.2: Mostly hypothetical scenarios with minimal real-world relevance
scoring_guide.1: Entirely hypothetical; no real-world connection or consequences

indicators.name: Interdisciplinary Integration
indicators.definition: Integrates multiple subject areas around place-based phenomena
indicators.assessment_question: Does the lesson connect multiple disciplines through place-based inquiry?

scoring_guide.5: Seamless integration of 3+ disciplines around place-based themes
scoring_guide.4: Clear connections across 2-3 subject areas
scoring_guide.3: Some interdisciplinary connections; could be strengthened
scoring_guide.2: Minimal cross-disciplinary integration
scoring_guide.1: Purely single-discipline; no integration

indicators.name: Indigenous & Local Knowledge Systems
indicators.definition: Respectfully incorporates mātauranga Māori and other indigenous knowledge about place
indicators.assessment_question: Does the lesson integrate Māori and indigenous perspectives on environment and place?

scoring_guide.5: Mātauranga Māori central; indigenous knowledge as valid epistemology; deep integration
scoring_guide.4: Substantive incorporation of Māori environmental knowledge
scoring_guide.3: Some inclusion of Māori perspectives; could be deeper
scoring_guide.2: Token reference to Māori knowledge; superficial
scoring_guide.1: No indigenous knowledge; only Western perspectives

indicators.name: Critical Place Consciousness
indicators.definition: Encourages critical examination of power relations, colonization, and current issues shaping place
indicators.assessment_question: Does the lesson promote critical analysis of power dynamics and historical forces shaping this place?

scoring_guide.5: Sophisticated analysis of colonization, power, justice; critical consciousness central
scoring_guide.4: Clear examination of power dynamics and historical impacts on place
scoring_guide.3: Some critical elements; limited depth in power analysis
scoring_guide.2: Minimal critical perspective; avoids power/conflict/injustice
scoring_guide.1: Uncritical celebratory tone; reinforces dominant narratives

cultural_responsiveness_integrated.label: Cultural Responsiveness & Māori Perspectives (Integrated)
cultural_responsiveness_integrated.definition: Holistic pedagogical approach that validates ALL students' cultural backgrounds, centers Māori perspectives as tangata whenua, honors Te Tiriti o Waitangi, integrates mātauranga Māori, and ensures cultural sustaining education
cultural_responsiveness_integrated.note: This dimension fully integrates general cultural responsiveness with Māori-specific indicators. Each indicator addresses both broad cultural diversity AND Māori perspectives as appropriate to Aotearoa NZ's bicultural educational context

core_literature.citation: Gay, G. (2010); Ladson-Billings, G. (1995); Paris, D. & Alim, H. S. (2017)
core_literature.key_contribution: Culturally responsive and sustaining pedagogies framework

core_literature.citation: Bishop, R. & Glynn, T. (1999); Smith, L. T. (2012); Ka Hikitia (2013)
core_literature.key_contribution: Māori education, Te Tiriti obligations, and decolonizing methodologies

indicators.name: Cultural Knowledge Validation (All Cultures Including Māori)
indicators.definition: Recognizes students' diverse cultural knowledge—including Māori whakapapa, Pacific heritage, Asian backgrounds—as legitimate academic resources
indicators.assessment_question: Does the lesson value ALL students' cultural backgrounds (especially Māori) as assets rather than deficits?

scoring_guide.5: Positions diverse cultural knowledge as central; explicitly values Māori and other cultural ways of knowing; students contribute cultural knowledge
scoring_guide.4: Clear validation of cultural diversity including Māori; incorporates cultural knowledge
scoring_guide.3: Acknowledges cultural diversity; some space for cultural knowledge sharing
scoring_guide.2: Minimal recognition of diversity; Māori and minority cultures marginalized
scoring_guide.1: Assumes monocultural mainstream; ignores or deficitizes cultural backgrounds

indicators.name: Te Reo Māori Integration
indicators.definition: Meaningful use of Te Reo Māori throughout lesson as living language, not tokenistic decoration
indicators.assessment_question: Is Te Reo Māori authentically integrated with correct macron usage and cultural appropriateness?

scoring_guide.5: Extensive meaningful Te Reo; subject vocabulary in Māori; whakataukī used; bilingual instruction; correct macrons
scoring_guide.4: Substantial Te Reo beyond basics; content-specific terms; generally correct
scoring_guide.3: Some Te Reo beyond greetings; attempts correct usage
scoring_guide.2: Minimal Te Reo (kia ora, ka pai only); may have errors
scoring_guide.1: No Te Reo OR incorrect/disrespectful usage

indicators.name: Mātauranga Māori & Multicultural Content
indicators.definition: Curriculum includes mātauranga Māori AND diverse cultural perspectives as valid knowledge systems
indicators.assessment_question: Does content reflect mātauranga Māori and multicultural perspectives, not just Pākehā/Western views?

scoring_guide.5: Mātauranga Māori central; rich multicultural content; diverse voices and perspectives; Māori epistemology respected
scoring_guide.4: Substantial Māori knowledge; clear multicultural representation beyond tokenism
scoring_guide.3: Some mātauranga Māori and cultural diversity; could be deeper
scoring_guide.2: Token inclusion; mostly Pākehā/Western content; Māori knowledge peripheral
scoring_guide.1: Monocultural Eurocentric; no mātauranga Māori; Western knowledge only

indicators.name: Culturally Responsive Pedagogy (Including Māori Approaches)
indicators.definition: Uses teaching strategies aligned with diverse cultural learning styles including Māori pedagogies (ako, tuakana-teina)
indicators.assessment_question: Does pedagogy reflect diverse cultural learning preferences including Māori collaborative and oral traditions?

scoring_guide.5: Multiple modalities; collaborative learning; storytelling; whakapapa; ako; respects Māori and diverse cultural learning styles
scoring_guide.4: Clear culturally responsive strategies; includes Māori pedagogical approaches
scoring_guide.3: Some responsive elements; attempts cultural accommodation
scoring_guide.2: Predominantly mainstream Western pedagogy; minimal cultural responsiveness
scoring_guide.1: Exclusively individualistic Western methods; culturally unresponsive

indicators.name: Tikanga & Cultural Protocols
indicators.definition: Demonstrates understanding of tikanga Māori and respects cultural protocols for all represented cultures
indicators.assessment_question: Does the lesson follow tikanga and embody values like manaakitanga, whanaungatanga, kaitiakitanga?

scoring_guide.5: Tikanga embedded; appropriate karakia/mihi; respects tapu; embodies Māori values; respects all cultural protocols
scoring_guide.4: Clear tikanga respect; follows cultural protocols appropriately
scoring_guide.3: Attempts tikanga with some gaps; generally respectful
scoring_guide.2: Limited cultural protocol awareness; may inadvertently violate tikanga
scoring_guide.1: Ignores tikanga; inappropriate use of sacred concepts; culturally insensitive

indicators.name: Māori Worldview & Diverse Cosmologies
indicators.definition: Represents Māori cosmology authentically while respecting other cultural worldviews
indicators.assessment_question: Are Māori and other cultural worldviews (whakapapa, mauri, wairua, mana) authentically represented?

scoring_guide.5: Māori worldview central; explores whakapapa, mauri, wairua; honors diverse cosmologies
scoring_guide.4: Clear Māori philosophical frameworks; authentic representation of cultural worldviews
scoring_guide.3: Some Māori concepts; limited depth or context
scoring_guide.2: Superficial or stereotyped; only Western individualistic worldview dominant
scoring_guide.1: No Māori worldview; monocultural Western perspective; may misrepresent

indicators.name: Te Tiriti Partnership & Community Collaboration
indicators.definition: Reflects genuine partnership with Māori community (whānau, hapū, iwi) as Treaty partners
indicators.assessment_question: Does the lesson involve authentic Māori community partnership and co-design?

scoring_guide.5: Co-designed with iwi/hapū; substantive whānau involvement; shared decision-making
scoring_guide.4: Clear Māori community partnership and consultation
scoring_guide.3: Some Māori community involvement; limited depth
scoring_guide.2: Token consultation; minimal genuine partnership
scoring_guide.1: No Māori partnership; developed without consultation

indicators.name: High Expectations with Cultural Scaffolding
indicators.definition: Maintains rigor while providing culturally appropriate supports for diverse learners including Māori
indicators.assessment_question: Does the lesson set high standards with scaffolds that respect Māori and diverse cultural ways of learning?

scoring_guide.5: Rigorous goals; multiple pathways to mastery; whakataukī and cultural metaphors as scaffolds; whānau support
scoring_guide.4: High expectations with culturally appropriate scaffolding
scoring_guide.3: Attempts rigor and cultural support; uneven
scoring_guide.2: Lowers expectations OR rigorous without cultural scaffolding
scoring_guide.1: Waters down content OR culturally unresponsive; deficit perspectives

indicators.name: Critical Cultural Consciousness & Decolonization
indicators.definition: Enables analysis of power, colonization's impacts, racism, and cultural privilege
indicators.assessment_question: Does the lesson develop critical consciousness about colonization, power, and cultural justice?

scoring_guide.5: Explicitly examines colonization, racism, power; centers Māori sovereignty; affirms tino rangatiratanga; decolonizing
scoring_guide.4: Clear analysis of cultural power dynamics and colonial impacts
scoring_guide.3: Some critical elements; limited depth in power/colonization analysis
scoring_guide.2: Superficial diversity celebration; avoids power/racism/colonization
scoring_guide.1: Ignores power and colonization; may reinforce colonial narratives and stereotypes

indicators.name: Cultural Sustaining & Te Reo Revitalization
indicators.definition: Actively sustains Māori language and culture while supporting all heritage languages and cultural practices
indicators.assessment_question: Does the lesson promote Te Reo revitalization and support students maintaining their cultural identities?

scoring_guide.5: Actively promotes Te Reo; supports all heritage languages; validates multilingualism; cultural identity development
scoring_guide.4: Clear support for Te Reo and cultural maintenance
scoring_guide.3: Some space for cultural expression; limited sustaining
scoring_guide.2: English-only pressures; requires mainstream conformity; Māori/heritage languages marginalized
scoring_guide.1: Assimilationist; heritage languages/cultures as obstacles; deficit views

critical_pedagogy.label: Critical Pedagogy & Student Engagement
critical_pedagogy.definition: Educational approach that develops critical consciousness, centers student agency, challenges oppression, connects to lived experiences, and promotes social justice action

core_literature.citation: Freire, P. (1970); hooks, b. (1994); Giroux, H. A. (2011)
core_literature.key_contribution: Critical pedagogy as liberation, conscientização, dialogic teaching, and transformative education

indicators.name: Power Structure Analysis
indicators.definition: Explicitly examines how power, privilege, and oppression operate systemically
indicators.assessment_question: Does the lesson enable students to analyze systems of power and structural oppression?

scoring_guide.5: Sophisticated systemic power analysis; examines institutional racism, classism, colonialism
scoring_guide.4: Clear examination of power structures and privilege
scoring_guide.3: Some power analysis; limited systemic understanding
scoring_guide.2: Superficial; treats power as individual not structural
scoring_guide.1: Ignores power; naturalizes inequality; no structural analysis

indicators.name: Questioning Dominant Narratives
indicators.definition: Encourages critical interrogation of mainstream narratives and hegemonic ideologies
indicators.assessment_question: Does the lesson prompt students to question taken-for-granted assumptions?

scoring_guide.5: Systematically deconstructs dominant narratives; analyzes whose voices centered/marginalized
scoring_guide.4: Clear critical questioning of mainstream assumptions
scoring_guide.3: Some questioning; limited critique of dominant narratives
scoring_guide.2: Mostly accepts mainstream narratives uncritically
scoring_guide.1: Reinforces dominant ideologies; discourages questioning

indicators.name: Student Agency & Voice
indicators.definition: Positions students as knowledge co-constructors with genuine agency and voice
indicators.assessment_question: Do students have genuine voice, choice, and authority in their learning?

scoring_guide.5: Students generate questions, share authority, co-create assessment; meaningful choice and agency
scoring_guide.4: Clear student voice and choice; students contribute to decisions
scoring_guide.3: Some student input; limited genuine agency
scoring_guide.2: Minimal student voice; teacher-directed
scoring_guide.1: Students passive recipients; no voice or agency; compliance-oriented

indicators.name: Dialogic Teaching & Collaborative Learning
indicators.definition: Employs dialogue and collaboration as central pedagogical approaches
indicators.assessment_question: Is teaching dialogic with collaborative learning opportunities?

scoring_guide.5: Genuine dialogue; collaborative problem-posing; mutual learning; teacher vulnerability
scoring_guide.4: Clear dialogic approach; substantive collaboration
scoring_guide.3: Some dialogue and collaboration; uneven implementation
scoring_guide.2: Mostly teacher-directed; limited genuine dialogue
scoring_guide.1: Teacher monologue; authoritarian; no collaboration

indicators.name: Lived Experience Centering
indicators.definition: Grounds curriculum in students' real lives, communities, and social realities
indicators.assessment_question: Does the lesson meaningfully connect to students' lived experiences and community issues?

scoring_guide.5: Curriculum emerges from students' lives; addresses real issues they face; validates experience
scoring_guide.4: Clear connections to lived experiences and community realities
scoring_guide.3: Some connection to students' lives; could be stronger
scoring_guide.2: Disconnected from students' lives; abstract exercises
scoring_guide.1: Entirely decontextualized; ignores students' realities

indicators.name: Social Justice Orientation
indicators.definition: Explicitly focuses on equity, justice, human rights, and challenging oppression
indicators.assessment_question: Does the lesson have clear social justice aims?

scoring_guide.5: Explicitly frames learning around justice; examines systemic inequities; explores resistance movements
scoring_guide.4: Clear social justice focus; addresses equity and rights
scoring_guide.3: Some justice elements; limited depth
scoring_guide.2: Mentions justice superficially; avoids structural inequity
scoring_guide.1: Avoids justice; individualizes social problems; maintains status quo

indicators.name: Praxis & Action for Change
indicators.definition: Connects critical reflection to concrete action for social transformation
indicators.assessment_question: Does the lesson support students taking action to address injustice?

scoring_guide.5: Action projects addressing real issues; community engagement; solidarity work; theory-practice integration
scoring_guide.4: Clear action component; students engage with real-world change
scoring_guide.3: Some action orientation; limited scope or authenticity
scoring_guide.2: Mostly academic analysis; minimal action component
scoring_guide.1: Purely academic; discourages activism; separates learning from action

indicators.name: Critical Reflexivity
indicators.definition: Cultivates examination of own assumptions, biases, positionality, and complicity
indicators.assessment_question: Does the lesson promote critical self-reflection on assumptions and privilege?

scoring_guide.5: Students examine own socialization, privilege, complicity; teacher models vulnerability; ongoing reflexivity
scoring_guide.4: Clear critical self-reflection component
scoring_guide.3: Some self-reflection; limited depth
scoring_guide.2: Minimal self-reflection; critical lens only applied externally
scoring_guide.1: No reflexivity; unexamined assumptions; teacher as neutral authority

lesson_design_quality.label: Lesson Design & Structural Quality
lesson_design_quality.definition: Overall quality of lesson plan structure, clarity, coherence, assessment design, and pedagogical soundness
lesson_design_quality.note: This dimension evaluates the technical quality and coherence of the lesson plan itself as an instructional document

core_literature.citation: Wiggins, G. & McTighe, J. (2005). Understanding by Design.

core_literature.key_contribution: Responsive teaching and differentiation for diverse learners

indicators.name: Clear Learning Objectives
indicators.definition: Learning objectives are specific, measurable, appropriate, and clearly stated
indicators.assessment_question: Are learning objectives clear, specific, and appropriate for the grade level?

scoring_guide.5: Highly specific, measurable objectives; clear alignment with curriculum; appropriate complexity
scoring_guide.4: Clear objectives; mostly specific and measurable
scoring_guide.3: Objectives present but could be more specific or clear
scoring_guide.2: Vague objectives; unclear expectations
scoring_guide.1: No clear objectives OR entirely inappropriate for level

indicators.name: Instructional Coherence & Flow
indicators.definition: Lesson has logical sequence, clear structure, and coherent progression of activities
indicators.assessment_question: Does the lesson have a logical, coherent structure with clear progression?

scoring_guide.5: Seamless logical flow; each activity builds on previous; clear beginning-middle-end structure
scoring_guide.4: Clear coherent structure; activities generally well-sequenced
scoring_guide.3: Some structure; flow could be improved; minor gaps in logic
scoring_guide.2: Disjointed; unclear progression; activities disconnected
scoring_guide.1: No clear structure; chaotic or incoherent

indicators.name: Assessment Alignment & Quality
indicators.definition: Assessments align with objectives, include formative and summative elements, and provide meaningful feedback mechanisms
indicators.assessment_question: Are assessments well-designed, aligned with objectives, and include both formative and summative elements?

scoring_guide.5: Excellent assessment design; clear alignment; multiple methods; rubrics; formative+summative; feedback loops
scoring_guide.4: Good assessment alignment; includes formative and summative; clear criteria
scoring_guide.3: Basic assessment present; alignment could be stronger
scoring_guide.2: Weak assessment; poor alignment; only one type (formative OR summative)
scoring_guide.1: No assessment OR entirely misaligned with objectives

indicators.name: Differentiation & Scaffolding
indicators.definition: Lesson includes appropriate scaffolds, differentiation strategies, and support for diverse learners
indicators.assessment_question: Does the lesson provide appropriate scaffolding and differentiation for diverse learners?

scoring_guide.5: Sophisticated differentiation; multiple pathways; graduated scaffolds; addresses varied needs
scoring_guide.4: Clear differentiation strategies; appropriate scaffolding
scoring_guide.3: Some scaffolding; limited differentiation
scoring_guide.2: Minimal scaffolding; one-size-fits-all approach
scoring_guide.1: No scaffolding or differentiation; inappropriate for learners

indicators.name: Resource Quality & Appropriateness
indicators.definition: Materials, resources, and tools are appropriate, well-selected, and enhance learning
indicators.assessment_question: Are resources and materials appropriate, high-quality, and well-integrated?

scoring_guide.5: Excellent resource selection; diverse materials; culturally appropriate; well-integrated
scoring_guide.4: Good resources; appropriate and supportive of objectives
scoring_guide.3: Adequate resources; could be higher quality or better integrated
scoring_guide.2: Poor resource selection; inappropriate or minimal
scoring_guide.1: No resources specified OR entirely inappropriate

indicators.name: Time Allocation & Pacing
indicators.definition: Realistic time estimates for activities with appropriate pacing throughout lesson
indicators.assessment_question: Is time allocation realistic and pacing appropriate for the lesson activities?

scoring_guide.5: Realistic timing; well-paced; appropriate balance of activities
scoring_guide.4: Generally realistic timing; mostly appropriate pacing
scoring_guide.3: Some timing issues; pacing could be improved
scoring_guide.2: Unrealistic time estimates; poor pacing
scoring_guide.1: No time considerations OR entirely unrealistic

indicators.name: Clarity & Usability
indicators.definition: Lesson plan is clearly written, well-organized, and usable by another teacher
indicators.assessment_question: Is the lesson plan clearly written and usable by another teacher?

scoring_guide.5: Exceptionally clear; highly detailed; any teacher could implement successfully
scoring_guide.4: Clear and well-organized; good usability
scoring_guide.3: Adequate clarity; some gaps in detail
scoring_guide.2: Unclear or poorly organized; difficult to follow
scoring_guide.1: Incomprehensible; unusable by others

composite_scoring.rationale: Cultural responsiveness (fully integrated with Māori perspectives) carries highest weight due to Te Tiriti obligations and bicultural commitments. Place-based learning and critical pedagogy equally weighted (25% each) for contextual and transformative education. Lesson design quality (15%) ensures technical instructional soundness.

interpretation_guide.90_100: Exceptional - Exemplary lesson demonstrating deep integration across all dimensions
interpretation_guide.80_89: Excellent - Strong lesson with clear evidence across most dimensions and indicators
interpretation_guide.70_79: Proficient - Good lesson with solid foundation; some areas for growth
interpretation_guide.60_69: Developing - Adequate lesson with significant room for improvement
interpretation_guide.50_59: Emerging - Basic lesson requiring substantial development
interpretation_guide.0_49: Inadequate - Lesson does not meet framework standards; major revision needed

usage_notes.context_specificity: Framework designed specifically for Aotearoa New Zealand K-12 context; requires significant adaptation for other settings due to Te Tiriti obligations and bicultural commitments
usage_notes.evaluation_process: Each indicator scored 1-5 using specific scoring guides; dimension scores calculated as weighted average of indicators; overall score calculated using dimension weights
limitations: Framework emphasizes specific theoretical traditions; acknowledges other valid pedagogical perspectives exist
Scoring involves professional judgment and interpretation; inter-rater reliability recommended
Cultural competence and knowledge of Te Tiriti required for accurate evaluation of cultural responsiveness dimension
Framework assumes lesson plans contain sufficient detail for meaningful evaluation
AI evaluation must be validated by human educators with appropriate cultural competence

version_history.v1.0: Initial framework with four separate dimensions (place_based, cultural_responsiveness, maori_perspectives, critical_pedagogy)
version_history.v2.0: Attempted merging of cultural_responsiveness and maori_perspectives; retained separate indicator sections
version_history.v3.0: Complete integration: unified cultural responsiveness indicators; added lesson design quality dimension; refined all scoring guides
